div.head: THE LIFE OF CERVANTES.
div.p: MIGUEL DE CERVANTES SAAVEDRA, who≈øe writings have thrown a lu≈øtre over Spain, amu≈øed Europe, and corrected his century, lived poor, unfortunate, and died almo≈øt forgotten; we were ignorant till within the≈øe few years, of the true place of his birth. Madrid, Seville, Lucene and Alcala, di≈øputed this honour with each other; thus Cervantes, like Homer, Camoens and many other great men, found ≈øeveral countries after his death, and wanted nece≈ø≈øaries during his life.

The Spani≈øh academy under the protection
of its ≈øovereign, has at length rendered the memory of Cervantes that homage which Spain has owed him for too long a time; they have publi≈øhed a ≈øplendid edition of Don Quixotte. It ≈øeemed as if they had believed that the magnificence of this publication could repair the injuries that the nation had done its author. His life is at the head, written after the mo≈øt exact re≈øearches, by a di≈øtingui≈øhed academician. I ≈øhall follow this authority, as far as regards facts, permitting my≈øelf to ≈øpeak o ‚Ä¢ the works of Cervantes, according to the ≈øentiments they have in≈øpired me with.

Cervantes was a gentleman, ≈øon to Roderigo Cervantes, and Leonora de Cortinas; he was born at Alcala de Henares, a city of new Ca≈øtile, the 9th day of October 1547, under the reign of the emperor Charles the fifth. From his infancy he loved books; he ≈øtudied in Madrid under a celebrated profe≈ø≈øor, where he very ≈øoon ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed the mo≈øt expert ≈øcholars. The grand ≈øcience of that time was latin and theology; the parents of Cervantes
intended to have made him an eccle≈øia≈øtic or a phy≈øician, the only lucrative profe≈ø≈øions in Spain; but he had ≈øtill this trait in common with many celebrated poets, of making ver≈øes in ≈øpight of his parents. An elegy on the death of Queen I≈øabella de Valois, a number of ≈øonnets, and a little poem called "Filene," were his fir≈øt e≈ø≈øays; the ≈ømall regard that they paid to the≈øe works appeared to him an inju≈øtice, he left Spain, and went to ≈øettle at Rome, where di≈øtre≈øs forced him to become valet de chambre to Cardinal Aquaviva.

Di≈øgu≈øted very ≈øoon with an employment ≈øo little fit for him, Cervantes became a ≈øoldier, and fought with di≈øtingui≈øhed valour in the famous battle of Lepanto, gained by Don John of Au≈øtria, in 1571: he received there a wound in his left hand from a mu≈øquet, of which he was lame all his life;‚Äîas a recompence for this wound he was put into the common ho≈øpital at Me≈ø≈øina. Having left the ho≈øpital, the trade of an invalid ≈øoldier appeared to him preferable to that of a de≈øpi≈øed
poet, he went and enrolled him≈øelf anew in the garri≈øon of Naples, in which city he remained three years. As he was repa≈ø≈øing into Spain on board a galley of Philip the Second's, he was taken and brought into Algiers, by Arnaut Mami, the mo≈øt renowned of all the cor≈øairs.

Fortune, who exhau≈øted her rigours upon the unfortunate Cervantes, could not wear out his courage;‚Äî≈ølave to a cruel ma≈øter, ≈øure of dying in torments if he dur≈øt make the lea≈øt attempt to recover his liberty, he concerted his e≈øcape with fourteen Spani≈øh captives. They agreed to redeem one from among them≈øelves who ≈øhould go to his own country, and return with a bark to carry the others during the night; the execution of his project was not very ea≈øy: it was nece≈ø≈øary at fir≈øt to get as much money as ≈øhould pay for the ran≈øom of one of the pri≈øoners, afterwards to e≈øcape from the hou≈øes of their different ma≈øters, and be able to remain all together, without being di≈øcovered, till the very moment that the bark ≈øhould arrive to carry them
away. So many difficulties appeared in≈øurmountable; the love of liberty brought it all about. A captive, a native of Navarre, employed by his ma≈øter in cultivating a large garden upon the borders of the ≈øea, took on him≈øelf the ta≈øk of hollowing out a cave in the mo≈øt retired part of the garden, capable of containing the fifteen Spaniards; he ≈øpent two years in this work, during which time they gained, what with alms and hard work, the ran≈øom of a Majorcan, named Viane, who≈øe fidelity they were ≈øure of, and who knew perfectly well all the coa≈øt of Barbary. The money being ready, and the cave being fini≈øhed, it was nece≈ø≈øary to wait yet ≈øix months before every one was prepared to go there; then Viane ran≈øomed him≈øelf, and parted from them, having ≈øworn to return in a little time.

Cervantes had been the ≈øoul of the enterprize; it was he who expo≈øed him≈øelf every night in ≈øeeking food for his companions; as ≈øoon as day appeared, he retired into the cave
with provi≈øions enough for the day. The gardener, who was not obliged to conceal him≈øelf, had his eyes continually on the ≈øea, to di≈øcover if the bark was yet come.

Viane kept his word; arrived at Majorea, he went to the viceroy, laid his commi≈ø≈øion before him, and demanded his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in favour of the enterpri≈øe; the viceroy gave him a brigatine. Viane, with his heart full of hope, flew to the deliverance of his brothers; he arrived on the coa≈øt of Algiers, the 28th day of September, of that ≈øame year 1577, one month from the day he had left it. Viane had ob≈øerved every place ≈øo well, that he knew them again altho' it was night, he directs his little ve≈ø≈øel towards the garden, where he was expected with ≈øo much impatience. The gardener, who was on the watch, perceived him, and ran to acquaint the captive Spaniards of it. All their misfortunes are forgotten at this happy news, they embrace each other, they pre≈øs to get out of the cave, they view with tears of joy the bark of their deliverer;
‚Äîbut alas! as the prow touched the ≈øhore, ≈øome Moors were pa≈ø≈øing that way, and knowing the Chri≈øtians, cried out to arms! Viane trembling ≈øpreads his ≈øails, gains the open ≈øea and di≈øappears; the unhappy captives, fallen again into their chains, went to weep at the bottom of their cave.

Cervantes re-animates them, he made them hope, and flattered him≈øelf that Viane would return again; but Viane returned no more. Grief, and the dampne≈øs of their narrow and unhealthy abode, brought di≈øorders on the≈øe unhappy people. Cervantes was no longer able to procure nece≈ø≈øaries for ≈øome, to take care of others, and to encourage all: he got one of his companions to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, and gave him the charge of providing victuals in his place. The per≈øon he made choice of was a traitor, he went to the King of Algiers, turned Mu≈ø≈øulman, and led him≈øelf to the cave, a troop of ≈øoldiers, who put the thirteen Spaniards in irons, and dragged them before the King; that Prince promi≈øed them their lives,
if they would declare who was the author of the enterpri≈øe;‚ÄîIt is I, ≈øaid Cervantes to him, ≈øave my brothers, and put me to death. The King re≈øpects his intrepidity, he gave him back to his ma≈øter Arnaut Mami, who would not put ≈øo brave a man to death.

The unhappy gardener, who had made the cave, was hung up by one leg, till his blood ≈ømothered him. Cervantes, deceived by fortune, betrayed by his friend, and returned to his fir≈øt chains, only became more ardent to break them; four times he failed in his attempts, and was on the point of being impaled. His la≈øt effort was to cau≈øe a revolt among all the ≈ølaves in Algiers, and to make him≈øelf ma≈øter of it; they di≈øcovered this con≈øpiracy, yet Cervantes was not put to death;‚Äî≈øo certain it is, that true courage will make it≈øelf re≈øpected even among barbarians.
It is true, that Cervantes being willing to ≈øpeak of him≈øelf, in the novel of the Captive, one of the mo≈øt intere≈øting in Don Quixotte, ≈øays,

p.q: That the cruel Azan, King of Algiers was never merciful only to a Spani≈øh ≈øoldier, named Saavedra; who expo≈øed him≈øelf often to the mo≈øt frightful puni≈øhments, which will not for a long time be forgotten by the infidels.

div.p:
In the mean time, the King of Algiers, willing to be the ma≈øter of ≈øo famous a captive, purcha≈øed him from Arnaut Mami, and had him clo≈øely confined. A ≈øhort time after, this Prince being obliged to go to Con≈øtantinople, demanded from Spain the ran≈øom of his pri≈øoner. The mother of Cervantes, Leonora de Cortinas, a widow and poor, ≈øold all that ≈øhe had, and ran to Madrid, carrying with her three hundred ducats to the fathers of the Trinity, who were charged with the redemption of captives. This money, which was the intire and only fortune of the widow, was far from being ≈øufficient. The King Azan would have five hundred crowns of gold; the Trinitarians, touched with compa≈ø≈øion, completed the ≈øum, and Cervantes was ran≈øomed
the 19th of September 1580, after a ≈ølavery of five years.

On his return to Spain, di≈øgu≈øted with a military life, and re≈øolving to deliver him≈øelf up entirely to letters, he retired near his mother, with the fond hope of ≈øupporting her by his works. Cervantes was then thirty three years old, he began with GALATEA, of which he gave but the fir≈øt ≈øix books, and which he never completed. This work ≈øucceeded pretty well; the ≈øame year he married Donna Catherine de Palacios, ≈øhe was de≈øcended from a good family, but ≈øhe was poor, and this marriage did not enrich him. To maintain his family, Cervantes wrote comedies; he a≈ø≈øures us, that they were well received, but very ≈øoon after this, he quitted the theatre for a ≈ømall employment which he obtained at Seville, where he went to ≈øettle. It was there he wrote tho≈øe novels where he paints ≈øo well the vices of that great city.

Cervantes was near fifty years old, when he was obliged to take a journey into La Mancha.
The inhabitants of a little village named Argamazilla, picked a quarrel with him, threw him into pri≈øon, and left him in it a long time; it was there that he began Don Quixotte, he believed that he ≈øhould revenge him≈øelf on tho≈øe who had in≈øulted him, by making their country the country of his hero. He affected in the mean time not to mention once in his romance, the town where he had been ≈øo badly treated. He began by giving to the public no more than the fir≈øt part of Don Quixotte, which did not ≈øucceed. Cervantes knew mankind; he publi≈øhed a pamphlet called "The Squib,"‚Äîthis work, which it would be impo≈ø≈øible to find now, even in Spain, ≈øeems to be a critici≈øm on Don Quixotte that covered his ≈ølanderers with ridicule;‚Äîevery one read the ≈øatire, and Don Quixotte obtained by this bagatelle, the reputation which ≈øince has been due only to it≈øelf.‚ÄîThen all the enemies of good ta≈øte let them≈øelves loo≈øe again≈øt Cervantes. Critici≈øms, ≈øatires, calumnies, all were ≈øet to work. More unhappy
by his ≈øucce≈øs, than ever he had been by his di≈øgraces, he dur≈øt not venture to give any thing to the public for ≈øeveral years, his ≈øilence added to his mi≈øery without appea≈øing envy. ‚ÄîHappily the Count de Lemos and the Cardinal of Toledo lent him ≈øome ≈øuccours; this protection, which Cervantes con≈øidered as ≈øo valuable, was continued to him almo≈øt to his death, but was never proportioned either to the merit of the protected, nor to the wealth of the protector. Cervantes, to ≈øhow his gratitude to the Count de Lemos, dedicated his novels to him, which appeared eight years after the fir≈øt part of Don Quixotte; the year following he gave his "Voyage to Parna≈ø≈øus," but the≈øe works brought him but little money, and the ≈øuccours of the Count de Lemos were always very weak, ≈øince Cervantes to procure bread was obliged to print eight comedies, which the players had refu≈øed to perform; he ≈øeemed de≈øtined to misfortunes and humiliations of every kind‚ñ™

This ≈øame year, an Arragonian, who took
the name of d'Avellaneda, wrote a continuation of Don Quixotte; a wretched continuation, without ta≈øte, without wit, and without gaiety, but in which he ≈øaid many things injurious to Cervantes;‚Äîthis ≈øort of merit made the book be read. Cervantes replied to it as all the ≈øatires ought to have been replied to: ‚Äîhe publi≈øhed the ≈øecond part of Don Quixotte, ≈øuperior ≈øtill to the fir≈øt, every one was convinced of his merit, but the more they were obliged to render him ju≈øtice, the le≈øs ≈øorry were they that a rival, even de≈øpicable, ≈øhould in≈øult him whom they were forced to admire.‚ÄîSpain is not, perhaps, the only country in the world, where malignity ≈øo ≈øevere on good works is always indulgent to their detractors. The ≈øecond part of Don Quixotte was the la≈øt work printed during his life;‚Äîhe worked ≈øtill at the romance of "Perfiles and Sigi≈ømunda," when he was attacked by a complaint of
which he died, it was a drop≈øy;‚Äîhe felt very ≈øoon that he could not be cured, and fearing not to have time to fini≈øh his work, augmented his di≈øorder by inten≈øe application. Four days before his death he had his romance of Per≈øiles brought to him, and traced with a feeble hand, the epi≈øtle dedicatory, addre≈ø≈øed to the Count de Lemos, who ju≈øt then arrived from Italy;‚Äîthis letter de≈øerves to be remembered‚Äî it is as follows:‚Äî

div.head: OF THE WORKS OF CERVANTES.
div.p:
THE fir≈øt poetical works of Cervantes are not much known, nor do they de≈øerve it;‚Äî his ≈øonnets and elegies are written too much in the ta≈øte of his age‚Äîhis be≈øt work, that which has immortalized his name, is the "Romance of Don Quixotte;"‚Äîthe judgment, the gaiety, the fine irony diffu≈øed through this work, the great truth of the portraits, the purity, the ≈øimplicity of the ≈øtyle, have rendered this work immortal: I know that it is not equally plea≈øing to all French readers who do not under≈øtand Spani≈øh; this ari≈øes
from the faults of the only tran≈ølation which we have of it, it is very far from the elegance and the delicacy of the original. The tran≈ølator ≈øeems to have con≈øidered Don Quixotte as a common romance, who≈øe ≈øole merit was to be entertaining. He has tran≈ølated the Spani≈øh word by the French one, which he found in the dictionary, without comparing or without chu≈øing; he forgot that in works of humour no word is ≈øynonimous to another; that one word alone is apt, and all others improper.

The manner in which he has tran≈ølated the pieces of poetry, of which there are many in Don Quixotte, would per≈øuade us that the Spani≈øh ver≈øes are ridiculous; when, in fact, they are all agreeable‚Äîperhaps too ab≈øtru≈øe.

But Cervantes wrote for his nation, who≈øe ta≈øte is different from ours; and the tran≈ølator, who wrote for us, ought, whil≈øt he pre≈øerved the thoughts of Cervantes, to have weakened ≈øome compari≈øons, ≈øoftened ≈øome of the images, and have, above all, given
≈øweetne≈øs and harmony to the ver≈øes. He appears to have thought of nothing but being literal, and this among the French, is con≈øidered as a fault. To us almo≈øt all foreign books ≈øeem too long; even Don Quixotte has prolixities and ≈øtrokes of bad ta≈øte, which might be retrenched without the tran≈ølator's meriting the reproach of not being exact; when a work of entertainment is to be tran≈ølated, the tran≈ølation mo≈øt agreeable, is, without doubt, the mo≈øt faithful.

Notwith≈øtanding the≈øe faults, the work is ≈øo excellent in it≈øelf, the epi≈øodes ≈øo intere≈øting, the adventures ≈øo comic, that all the world knows it, all the world read it again and again;‚Äîour tape≈øtry, our pictures and our prints, all repre≈øent Don Quixotte to us; and even the children laugh when they ≈øee Sancho Panza.

Cervantes's novels fall far ≈øhort of Don Quixotte; he wrote twelve, and four alone are worthy of him,‚Äî"The Curious Impertinent,"
which is in≈øerted in Don Quixotte; "Riconnet and Cortadille," a whim≈øical but true picture of the rogues of Seville:‚Äî"The Force of Blood," the mo≈øt intere≈øting and be≈øt conducted of the whole;‚Äîand "The Dialogue of the Dog?." This la≈øt is a charming piece of critici≈øm, abounding with philo≈øophy and gaiety; the Spani≈øh manners are there drawn with all the accuracy, ≈øimplicity, and ≈øpirit of Cervantes. We have had within tho≈øe few years a French tran≈ølation of the≈øe twelve novels, but they ought to be read in the original.

The "Journey to Parna≈ø≈øus," is a poetical work, divided into chapters. Cervantes feigns that Apollo threatened by legions of bad poets, ≈øends Mercury into Spain, to a≈ø≈øemble all his favourites, and conduct them to defend Parna≈ø≈øus. Mercury finds Cervantes, and ≈øhows him the li≈øt of tho≈øe whom Apollo requires to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, and of their adver≈øaries. It is evident what a fine opportunity this fiction gave a man of wit to be revenged on the
dunces who had in≈øulted him. This work is not very agreeable, nor can we reli≈øh it highly; I know not any tran≈ølation of this, nor of his comedies; they are eight in number, and Cervantes ≈øays in his prologue, that he had written twenty or thirty; this uncertainty mu≈øt appear wonderful to tho≈øe who know how difficult it is to write even one comedy;‚Äîbe that as it may, tho≈øe which are pre≈øerved, dimini≈øh our regret for tho≈øe that are lo≈øt. I have read them all with attention, none of them are tolerable; unintere≈øting, badly conducted, often witty, always improbable; ≈øuch is the characteri≈øtic of all his plays. In that called "The Happy Ruffian," the hero, who in the fir≈øt act is the greate≈øt villain in Seville, becomes a Jacobin at Mexico in the ≈øecond: he is the pattern of the convent; he has frequent encounters with the devil, upon the ≈øtage, and always remains conqueror. Being called to attend a lady of the place, then on her death-bed, who≈øe life had been very irregular, Father Crux, for ≈øo he is called, pre≈ø≈øes her in vain, to confe≈øs her ≈øins; the dying lady
